comment._content: AS a starter, this pic is post-1889, when my great-grandfather was killed while working on the extension to the original building.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: We can only imagine how difficult and dangerous construction/building work would have been in those days……without all the OH&S regulations we have in place these days.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I am not 100% sure about this, but here goes: The Royal Exchange was known as the Merchants' Exchange before a Royal title from King Edward VII in 1901. That is why it does not show in old Trove searches. On 19/10/1899 they met to discuss alterations and additions to the building ( trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14228147 ) The additions must have been complete by 31/12/1900 - " On 31 December, 1900, the evening of the inauguration of the Commonwealth of Australia, the statue of "Commerce", designed by sculptor James White who also created the Statue of Liberty, on top of the building was unveiled. It stood there until 1964 when the building was demolished. It has now been given pride of place outside the refurbished building looking over Pitt Street. " ( www.56pittstreetsydney.com/jd/jadehttp.dll?EbdMulti_www_0... I think these additions are what we see here, dating this photo as early 1900. Maybe?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I initially thought that with sufficient resolution, it might be possible to date some of the Lands Office pics by the statues...but I'm less enthused by the idea now...from what I can gather via the digitised newspapers, most of the statues appear to have been added within a relatively brief period during 1891-1893...with others added in the early 20th century...and one in November 2010!...all up I suspect that dating by statue will have a fairly limited application...so far, all the pics of the Lands Office I've seen (post additions) show the 12 Bridge St statues in place...and in most instances I'd say that other dating landmarks will prove more useful...so far I've managed to put statue dating to use on a couple of pics - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362676015/ ; www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3023701142/ ; www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/9147142897/ Per this 1892 letter, it appears that the Lands Office statues might have been the idea of architect James Barnet - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13884682 This 1894 T&CJ answers column item lists the Lands Office statues then in place and gives their general location ('Sydney Statues', column 2) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5241239... This 1931 SMH article is maybe worth a read - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16824171 I'm still trying to establish when a few of the statues were placed...it's probably safe to assume that the statues haven't been moved around over the years, and that they're still in their original locations...but it would be good to find contemporary reports which refer to the locations... SUMMARY: Each of the four Lands Office facades has 12 statue niches...only the Bridge St facade has a full complement of statues. Bridge St (12 statues) - Banks and Leichhardt were evidently the first of the Bridge St statues to be put in place...they were added on 12/2/1891...Oxley appears to have been the last of the Bridge Street statues...added on 12/7/1893... ...I've noted the positions of the Bridge St statues at - www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/9147142897/ ; www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2779693843/ Bent St - (6 statues) - ...the various newspaper items indicate that the four lower level statues were put in place during 1892-1893...the first appears to have been Wentworth...added 5/3/1892...then Robertson...ca. September 1892; Cunningham...ca. January 1893; Blaxland...ca. April 1893...I have yet to establish when the two middle level statues were added...one newspaper item indicates Lawson was in place in January 1894...Farnell was a somewhat later addition...news items indicate the order for Farnell was approved in June 1901... and that he was added by October 1903. Gresham St - (4 statues)...all occupy lower level niches...Deniehy appears to have been the first of the Gresham St statues to be added in September 1901, Grey was added on 21/10/1901. Parkes was still a clay model in August 1901 so might not have been added until some time later...maybe not until 1902. I still haven't found a report re Martin, but one news item indicates that orders for Parkes and Martin were approved in June 1901, so maybe Martin was added at about the same time as Parkes... Loftus St - (2 statues)...Stuart (25/1/1902) was the only addition until Meehan in November 2010... SOURCES/REPORTS ON STATUES ADDED: Sir Joseph Banks (Bridge St), Ludwig Leichhardt (Bridge St), 12/2/1891 (item bottom column 1) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1378508 ; also see this T&CJ item - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71249373 ; Burke (Bridge St), Wills (Bridge St), ca. June 1891 (item columns 1-2) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5974928 ; W.C. Wentworth (Bent St), 5/3/1892 (item column 8) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13864469 ; Governor Arthur Phillip (Bridge St), 23/5/1892 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64030791 ; George Bass (Bridge St) 27/6/1892 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article112940809 ; also see this T&CJ item which has a pic - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71202700 ; Matthew Flinders (Bridge St), ca.July/August 1892 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13874180 ; Sir John Robertson (Bent St), ca. September 1892 (item column 8) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13878861 ; Sir Thomas Mitchell (Bridge St) 28/10/1892 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71205877 ; Hovell (Bridge St) 9/11/1892 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103410996 ; this item has pics of both the Hovell and Mitchell statues - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71207262 ; Charles Sturt (Bridge St) - late July or Early August 1892...possibly at the same time as Flinders - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article112602891 ; news.google.com/newspapers?id=yRhQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l5UDA... ; Allan Cunningham (Bent St), 26/1/1893 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13895172 ; Hamilton Hume (Bridge St), ca. March 1893 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article98534190 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71197279 ; Gregory Blaxland (Bent St), ca. April 1893 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article112611149 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64033382 ; John Oxley (Bridge St), 12/7/1893 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113728744 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71187214 ; Lawson...was added by January 1894...this January 1894 Illustrated Sydney News item refers to a number of the Lands Office statues, including Lawson - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63104972 Sir Henry Parkes (Gresham St), presumably well after July/August 1901 when the clay model was on view - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71470532 ; Daniel Deniehy (Gresham St), ca. September 1901 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article114027958 ;also see news.google.com/newspapers?id=wAFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-5QDA... ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article61289110 ; Sir George Grey (Gresham St), 21/10/1901 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article112577508 ; news.google.com/newspapers?id=wgFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-5QDA... ; John McDowell Stuart (Loftus St), 25/1/1902 (lower down column 1)...this report refers to Stuart as the 19th statue...which suggests that Parkes might not yet have been added - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1340349 ...also see this T&CJ item - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71520760 ; James Meehan (Loftus St), November 2010 - www.baseline.nsw.gov.au/exhibitions/meehan/index.html ; this June 1901 SMH item refers to Daniel Deniehy (cost of statue), and orders for Sir Henry Parkes, Sir James Martin (Gresham St) and James Squire Farnell (Bent St)...(3rd last item column 8) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14391457 ; this October 1903 SMH item on the SCG indicates Farnell was in place by then (see 'The Civil Service Club') - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71486613 ! Here's an 1892 letter from explorer and author Ernest Favenc, lobbying for John McDowell Stuart - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13887565 ; ! Here's Favenc again, in 1902, after the Stuart statue had been added - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14446163 www.publicartaroundtheworld.com/Lands_Department_Building...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's a link to the Sydney Mail item on the Lands Office building which appeared in September 1891, when the additions were evidently nearing completion...there's a sketch a few pages earlier - news.google.com/newspapers?id=OM0QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TpMDA... ...this November 1892 SMH item indicates that the additions were nearing completion then (!) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13884915

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Statue dating in action! ...it's a bit difficult to tell at the available resolution, but this SLNSW pic appears to show only 11 of the Bridge St statues in place...with Oxley's perch (far left, middle level) still vacant...unless Oxley decided to go for a walk one day, or was temporarily removed for some reason, statue dating suggests that this SLNSW pic was taken some time after the 11th Bridge St statue was added (Hume, early 1893) but before Oxley put in an appearance (ca. July 1893). Of course, in this SLNSW pic, all the Gresham St niches are empty...and they remained so until the first of the Gresham St statues were added in ca. October 1901. This pic appears in - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=401890

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: If anyone is interested, I've also done a bit of statue dating over at the Col Sec's Building - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3793507471/

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=152951&amp... - check pic No 51 in this album from the SLNSW collection (it's on page 6)...here we see six of the Bridge St statues in place and six vacant niches...of the six statues in place, Bass (top corner lhs) was the last added ca. 27/6/1892...whilst the next statue to be added, Flinders (rh corner, middle tier), isn't there yet. Flinders was added in ca. July-August 1892...all up, statue dating suggests the pic must have been taken between ca. 27/6/1892 thru to some time in early August 1892.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] W. P. MacIntosh was the sculptor of 10 of the statues on the Lands Department Building, but I've only figured out 4 of them so far (granted it has been 18 months since I last did any Troving on the question). See comments here - www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/6324670791/ [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/galleries/72157628097692596/]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Hey that's brilliant! ...Next time I'm in Sydney I'm seriously considering rigging a camera up on a long telescopic pole and maybe taking some half decent photos of the Lands Office statues (if I don't get arrested in the process)...to do it properly I suspect you'd need a cherry picker and some decent lighting...and then maybe hire a serious camera for a few days...

The Bridge St statues are such fantastic expressions of late 19th century Australian settlement narratives...and I just love the way Favenc lobbied (successfully) to have the statue of Stuart included...even if he did end up being hidden away around the corner in Loftus St.

I notice the NSW Government is considering selling the Lands Office! Presumably the statues come with the building.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] As it turns out...with a few more newspapers now digitised, a good deal can be established on the sculptors of the various Lands Office statues...it's not entirely clear, but W.P. MacIntosh and James Fillans appear to have collaborated on some of the initial statues to be placed in position. Macintosh was also responsible for the Royal Arms (Bent St facade) and the NSW state badge (Loftus St facade) - www.brucehassan.id.au/MatrixMacintosh.html Banks; Leichhardt - ?MacIntosh/Fillans (bottom of column 1) nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1378508 Burke; Wills - ?MacIntosh/Fillans (columns 1-2) nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5974928 Hovell; Mitchell - MacIntosh nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71207262 Flinders - MacIntosh nla.gov.au/nla.news-article112602891 Hume - MacIntosh nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71197279 Sturt - MacIntosh - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13887565 Oxley - McIntosh nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71187214 Stuart - MacIntosh nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4905185 Wentworth; Cunningham - Tomaso Sani - adb.anu.edu.au/biography/sani-tomaso-4537 Robertson - Tomaso Sani (column 8) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13878861 Phillip; Bass - James White nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64030791 Blaxland; Deniehy - James White www.daao.org.au/bio/james-white/biography/ Grey - Sherrif & Son nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14415795 Parkes - Nelson Illingworth nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71470532 Lawson - ? Martin - Tomaso Sani nla.gov.au/nla.news-article114032172 Farnell - ?Forti nla.gov.au/nla.news-article114031692 Meehan - ?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] A slightly tongue-in-cheek site with a lot of info about the Lands Department Building statues - www.publicartaroundtheworld.com/Lands_Department_Building...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Some fairly good pics of the statues here too! I wonder whether State Records of NSW might have a file buried away somewhere which might shed more light on a few of the statues.

As of April 2013, the NSW Government has indicated that it intends to sell the Lands Office...if this eventuates and the Lands Office is sold off to the highest bidder and turned into a gambling den with a massage parlour upstairs (the fate of another notable 19th century public building elsewhere in Australia), I'd be deeply concerned for the moral well being of quite a few of these statues. Having spent their lives roaming in the wilderness and enduring hardship, the explorers are by temperament ill equipped to resist the temptations which will be on offer, and of course for many of the politicians it might well be a case of returning to former habits! Deniehy in particular will be in dire peril! All up, it's a wonder that the NSW Government's bean counters haven't canvassed the idea of flogging off the statues separately. For the building's new owners they'd be superfluous to requirements and I'm sure there'd be many a well-heeled discerning collector out there who'd jump at the chance to bid for a brace of explorers and politicians, given the chance.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14351657 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14338763 - per these 1901 SMH items, much/most of the work on the addition to the Sydney Exchange was completed in 1900...with some work continuing into 1901...which confirms [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] 's findings re the date 1900 above. ... nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14387206 re the Royal Exchange ...per this item, the prenom 'Royal' was dubbed in May 1901...also see the brief news report on the next page.
